If it was me and I had a choice. I would rewrite the private methods to 
be more amenable to testing. It seems to me that in your case you have 
access to the source else you would not be able to test those methods no 
matter what ... if you just had access to the class files.

Going against my better judgement here's a nice sloppy solution (you 
have been forewarned !!). Now assuming you have the source and you are 
absolutely dead against modifying those private methods, but don't mind 
adding a few extra public methods. Then you could write a public 
accessor function (gasp) for each private method you needed to test, 
that would return the array object after the private method did it's 
work. That way you could compare the state of the array before and after 
each invocation and see if the desired state was achieved. You could put 
all these public accessor functions into an inner class, and then drop 
the compiled inner class when you are ready to release your class.

So if your class is Something.java and you have an inner class Test. You 
can delete the Something$Test.class <ensure that no other function 
within class Something depends on the inner Test class>.

Please note if you can refactor your private methods, then do that  by 
all means

-george


rajeshwari_83 wrote:

> There is a class which has one public method returning an ArrayList.
> The public method of this class inturn calls several private methods
> which are void. These private methods only keep adding to the
> arraylist which is finally returned by the public method. I need to
> write a JUNIT for this class specifically the private methods of this
> class. Since these methods are void, how do I write JUNIT test cases
> for them???
>
>
